Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effects of Preoperative Midazolam on Postoperative Sleep in Children

Trial_Design.evidence: Seventy children aged 3 to 12 years were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: This two-group randomised controlled trial was conducted at Yale-New Haven Childrenâ€™s Hospital. Seventy children aged 3 to 12 years

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either preoperative acetaminophen only (control group, n = 32) or both acetaminophen and midazolam (experimental group, n = 38)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of preoperative midazolam on postoperative sleep in children undergoing tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative sleep, measured using actigraphy.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: control group, n = 32 or both acetaminophen and midazolam (experimental group, n = 38)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Children in the midazolam group were awake significantly less during the night compared to the control group (p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
